subject: Re: Let me introduce myself...
msgSnippet: ... Thanks! ... Yes, sort of, altho the location of characters in a font and the location of font characters to keys on a keyboard are strictly speaking
messageBody:
Paige Gabhart wrote in response to my questions:

> Welcome Benct:

Thanks!

>
> I assume the preceding question is referring to the keyboard
> layout.

Yes, sort of, altho the location of characters in a font
and the location of font characters to keys on a keyboard
are strictly speaking independent of each other keyboard
remapping utilities are not on every Windows-user's
computer, and those that exist are not trivial to use.

> The standard keyboard layout is based upon the layout
> which was in use on the Shavian site when this site was
> started. I did not find it particularly appealing or
> intuitive for QS although one can get used to it.

Ah, historical debris. In my experience the bane of all
sensible standardization! :) I guess you can get used to
anything with enough time and motivation, but then there is
also the problem that not all solutions are convenient to
all people.

> I believe
> part of the "logic" used is based on some of the symbols used
> by the International Phonetic Alphabet. This is fine if you
> happen to know the IPA, but it is my contention that if we
> want to reach the general population of English writers who
> were taught traditional orthography (T.O.) in school, the IPA
> is no help because the general public knows little or nothing
> about it. It makes more sense to me to use a system that has
> some relation to T.O. which English readers and writers do
> know about.

I know IPA quite well, as I have studied phonetics and am
generally interrested in writing systems, but I nevertheless
find it irksome that /j/ (Ye) is mapped to the |j| key, and
not to the |y| key. I also would prefer the heavy vowels
(Eight, Eat, I, Owe, Ewe) mapped to the upper-case vowels
|A E I O U|. To map 40+ characters sensibly to 2*26 keys
in a manner that pleases everybody is of course a well-nigh
impossible task...

> Therefore, several people worked together to come up with an
> alternate keyboard mapping which seems more intuitive to me
> than what the Shavian group is using. This requires the use
> of the program "Keyman."

I tried an earlier version of Keyman, but found some aspects
of it cumbersome. The current version is perhaps better, but
due to its price I haven't been able to try it. The best free
utility I've found is the Microsoft Keyboard Layout Creator
<http://www.microsoft.com/globaldev/tools/msklc.mspx>,
which I have used not only to add Icelandic and Danish/Norwegian
characters to my Swedish keyboard layout, but also to create a
custom Slavic Philology keyboard layout for a friend. It is
likely that I will create a QS layout working on the same
mnemonics as my application of Swedish shorthand to English,
since I am already well familiar with its correspondances.

> One advantage which Keyman permits
> is that the numerous English vowels, which are now represented
> in T.O. by two vowels placed together, can be mapped to the
> appropriate QS symbol by typing the two vowels one after the
> other.

Yes that's neat. The Summer Institute of Linguistics used to
give away a Keyman-like utility for the Macintosh, and I made
an input system on these principles for my professors wife.
Alas I'm not on a Macintosh anymore!

> I find this easier to remember than altering the
> keyboard vowel letter by using the shift key, and it may be
> faster too since you don't have to move your little fingers to
> the shift key.

Yes. Even AltGr has something to recommend it, as it is
operated with the thumb, as long as the other key is under
the left hand...

> If you find none of the alternatives on the
> website appealing, Keyman permits you to put together you own
> keymapping that works for you if you choose to.

I probably will when I can afford Keyman...

> Some people
> may argue that we need to agree on a standard mapping, and in
> the long run that may be true. At this time, however, I'm
> unlikely to run into QS on someone else's computer, and I
> don't think that is likely to change any time soon.

BTW has there been any attempts to get QS into Unicode?

> Spread the word about QS to your friends who are interested in
> a more efficient way to write in English.

I will, but frankly I see it as the main drawback of QS that it is
so strongly wedded to the English language. It is not easily
adapted to other languages. There may still be a couple of
centuries before the whole planet speaks English, if ever, and
anyway it is nothing I look forward to!

> > Do speakers of American accents with merger between the vowels
> > of father-cot-caught spell accordingly? And if so, which
> > letter
> > do they use?
>
> I consistently distinguish between the vowels you are asking
> about, but would expect that a person whose idiolect has
> merged these vowels would use only the short "o" ["on" in
> Shavian] sound to symbolize all three when writing in QS.

Yes, I suppose the graphically most simple letter would be the
natural choice! While father-cot merger is the rule in North
America the cot-caught merger is AFAIK still confined to Canada,
and to the youngest generations in the US. How I as a European
came to have such an accent is a long story, but I have.

Is it a matter of concern to QS users that QS spelling itself
runs the risk of becoming "traditionalized"? I'm thinking not
only of the American vowel mergers mentioned, but also of the
vocalization of /l/ in the south of England, which is currently
wreaking havoc with the vowel systems there.
--

/BP 8^)>
